caption:
The photograph appears to depict an expansive outdoor scene focusing on environmental themes. In the foreground, a large tree stump takes center stage, its intricately patterned surface showcasing the natural rings and ridges of the tree's cross-section, some parts filled with what appears to be moss or a similar plant. This stump represents a poignant symbol of deforestation or tree cutting.

Beyond the stump, the image opens up into a broad, hilly landscape that dips into valleys and rises into distant mountains. The terrain is extensively cleared with few to no trees visible, suggesting recent logging activity or a similarly altered land use. Small paths or roads carve through the landscape, meandering through the hills and valleys. The background features layers of rolling mountains under a hazy sky, possibly indicative of mist, dust, or smoke.

The overall composition uses the stark contrast between the tree stump in the foreground and the altered landscape in the background to perhaps make a statement on human impact on natural environments. The use of lighting and perspective draws the viewerâ€™s eye from the detailed texture of the stump out towards the expansive view, emphasizing the scale and potential consequences of tree cutting and land use changes.
title: A (planted) Douglas fir seedling and the stump of the Douglas fir it is to replace in the foreground with a long shot view of a clear-cut in the Olympic National Timberland, Washington. Near Olympic National Park, Washington. From the Environmental Protection Agency's DOCUMERICA collection, "In Praise of Forests". For additional images see Fiche #s 209, 210, 211, 212, and 213. ENTHEOS. April, 1973.
